coredata.dc:title: Application of VMCM method to assess the implementation of Sustainable Development Goal 7 in EU countries
coredata.prism:issueName: 27th International Conference on Knowledge Based and Intelligent Information and Engineering Sytems (KES 2023)
coredata.dc:creator: Ogonowski, Piotr
coredata.dc:description: Everyday life and the workings of the economy depend on reliable and affordable energy services, such as electricity supply. Guaranteeing universal access to sustainable energy services is fundamental for socioeconomic development. This paper assessed the implementation of the sustainable development goal in the European Union countries in the seventh area "Affordable and clean energy" out of seventeen Sustainable Development Goals (SDG7) formulated in the document “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”. To assess the implementation of the seventh objective, the VMCM method was used, which allows for the ranking and classification of objects described with many features as representing the dynamics of changes in the studied phenomenon. As a result, each EU country was assigned to one of four classes appointed by the level of goal achievement SDG7. The country with the highest value of level of goal were assigned to Class 1, while those measured the lowest were assigned to Class 4. It presented in dynamic perspective comparing changes over 9 years (since year 2012 to 2021).
coredata.dcterms:subject: Sustainable Development Goals
Affordable and Clean Energy
Vector Measure Construction Methods (VMCM)

E-mail address: piotr.ogonowski@usz.edu.pl 4944 Piotr Ogonowski et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4943â€“49512 Piotr Ogonowski/ Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 1. Introduction At the turn of the 1970s and 1980s, the idea of sustainable development was born [1,2]. The concept of sustainable development was first comprehensively described in the report 1987 entitled â€œOur Common Futureâ€�, developed by the United Nations World Commission on Environment and Development, also referred to as â€œBrundtland Commissionâ€�[3]. The main direction in the concept of sustainable development is the well-being of the current and future generations [4-7], which is why this concept is the basis for estimating the level of human development in various economies, as well as assessing the effectiveness of programs and development policies applied in them. At the Sustainable Development Summit, which took place in 25 September 2015 in New York, during the plenary session of the UN General Assembly, representatives of the governments of 193 member states reached an agreement on the final document: "Transforming our world: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development"[8]. It contains 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). and 169 tasks to eradicate poverty and build a more sustainable world over the next dozen or so years. The SDGs address key systemic barriers to sustainable development such as inequality, unsustainable consumption patterns, weak institutional capacity and environmental degradation [9]. SDGs are called global goals and are treated as road signs valid until 2030 to lead all entities to a more prosperous, just and peaceful world. Using the definition from the report of the Bruntland Commission [3], sustainable development in 2030, the Agenda is understood as intergenerational solidarity consisting in finding such solutions that guarantee further growth, which allow all social groups to be actively involved in development processes, while giving them the opportunity to benefit from economic growth. To achieve sustainable development, therefore, the coherence of three key elements is required: economic growth, social inclusion and environmental protection, which are interconnected and extremely important for achieving the well-being of individuals and entire societies [10,11]. Since 2001, the European Union Strategy for Sustainable Development has been implemented. Sustainable development has officially become one of the European Union's long-term objectives under Article 3(3) of the Treaty on European Union. The European Union (EU) has fully committed itself to delivering on the 2030 Agenda, and the SDGs form an intrinsic part of the European Commissionâ€™s work programme. The European Union countries have adjusted the indicators for monitoring development progress, approved in May 2017, to the 17 SDGs. Based on these indicators, a report was prepared in October 2017, which is the beginning of Eurostat's regular monitoring of progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals in the context of the EU. The set of indicators includes 100 indicators organized according to 17 Sustainable Development Goals, but for each of the SDGs, the focus is on aspects relevant to the EU [12]. Monitoring is an essential component in realising the 2030 Agendaâ€™s vision, both globally and in the EU, by assessing and visualising the progress made so far towards the 17 SDGs. Since 2017, Eurostat has been preparing annual reports monitoring the progress towards the SDGs in the EU context. The concept of sustainable development takes on special importance during the scarcity of fossil fuels and the disruption of the global energy market caused by the Russian invasion of Ukraine. On 8 March 2022, the European Commission proposed the outline of a plan to make Europe independent from Russian fossil fuels well before 2030, in light of Russia's invasion of Ukraine [13]. There is a double urgency to transform Europe's energy system: ending the EU's dependence on Russian fossil fuels, which are used as an economic and political weapon, and tackling the climate crisis. Guaranteeing universal access to energy services is strategical for socioeconomic development. There can be no sustainable development without universal access to affordable, reliable and sustainable energy. Sustainable Development Goal 7 called â€žAffordable and clean energyâ€� calls for ensuring universal access to modern energy services, improving energy efficiency and increasing the share of renewable Energy. In this context, of energy transformation has unusual dimensions: legal and political, technological, economic and, above all, social. Therefore, this problem should be treated as a multidimensional issues described by many indicators. Multidimensional Comparative Analysis (MCA) is an adequate approach, which can have the possibility for an objective with automated analysis and finding solutions for the problem under consideration. This group of methods include also, for example: TOPSIS (The Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution) TOPSIS [14-15], VIKOR (Vlse Kriterijumska Optimizacija Kompromisno Resenje) which means multicriteria optimization and compromise solution, in Serbian [16-18], HELLWIG [19], and VMCM (Vector Measure Construction Methods) [20-22]. The aim of the article is to examine the possibility of using and usefulness of the VMCM method to assess the implementation of SDG 7 â€œAffordable and clean energyâ€�. The example used in this study concerns the assessment of 28 EU countries in terms of Affordable and clean energy. The analysis with using VMCM method will be based Piotr Ogonowski et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4943â€“4951 4945 Piotr Ogonowski/ Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 3 on the Eurostat database. Selected indicators of SDG 7 â€“ (affordable and clean energy) from the year 2012 - 2021 will be taken into account and analysed [23]. 2. Materials and Methods In this research the VMCM (Vector Measure Construction Method) method used was applied as a methodical tool to assess Sustainable Development - Goal 7. A group of SDGs indicators obtained from the Eurostat database [23], covering the time horizon of 2012-2021, was analyzed. They are related to the 7th Sustainable Development Goal in the context of the EU. This group (one of seventeen) marked as "Affordable and clean energy" includes the following indicators [24]: x1 â€“ final energy consumption in households per capita (in KGOE - Kilogram of oil equivalent); x2 â€“ energy productivity (ii Euro per kilogram of oil equivalent (KGOE)); x3 â€“ population unable to keep home adequately warm by poverty status (in %); x4 â€“ renewable energy sources in heating and cooling (in %); x5 â€“ renewable energy sources in transport (in %); x6â€“ renewable energy sources in electricity (in %); x7â€“ final energy consumption (in Million tonnes of oil equivalent); x8â€“ primary energy consumption (in Million tonnes of oil equivalent); x9â€“ energy import dependency by products (in %); Analyzed countries (variants) were: Austria (AT), Belgium(BE), Bulgaria(BG), Croatia(HR), Cyprus(CY), Czechia(CZ), Denmark(DK), Estonia(EE), Finland(FI), France(FR), Germany(DE), Greece(EL), Hungary(HU), Ireland(IE), Italy(IT), Iceland(IS), Latvia(LV), Lithuania(LT), Luxembourg(LU), Malta(MT), Netherlands(NL), Norway(NO), Poland(PL), Portugal(PT) Romania(RO), Slovakia(SK), Slovenia(SI), Spain(ES), Sweden(SE). Data referred to the year 2012-2021 and were obtained from the Eurostat database. 2.1. Vector Measure Construction Method The VMCM method utilizes the vector calculus properties in order to build vector synthetic measure (basing on the definition of the scalar product) [25]. Such an approach enables for making ranking, classification of objects and study of change dynamics. The procedure of VMCM comprises 8 stages [26]: Stage 1-2. Selection and elimination of variables In the paper the diagnostic variables was selected as expert judgment (substantive) method. Elimination of variables is carried out by using significance coefficient of features [27-29]: i i x x V i ï�³ï€½ , (1) where: ix â€“ i-th variable, iï�³ â€“ standard deviation of the i-th variable, ix â€“ mean value of the i-th variable, whereas: n x x n j j i i ïƒ¥ ï€½ï€½ 1 , (2) and 4946 Piotr Ogonowski et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4943â€“4951 4 Piotr Ogonowski/ Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 1 2 1 ï€­ ïƒ· ïƒ¸ ïƒ¶ ïƒ§ ïƒ¨ ïƒ¦ ï€­ ï€½ ïƒ¥ ï€½ n xx n j i j i iï�³ . (3) The significance coefficient values of the variables must be within the range <0;0,1> the variable which is outside of this range should be eliminated from the set of diagnostic variables [27-29]. Stage 3. Defining the diagnostic variables character The diagnostic variables character may have: (stimulants, destimulants and nominants). Stimulants are such variables, which greater values mean the higher level of development of complex socio-economic studied process. In the research the variables which has stimulants character are: x1 â€“ final energy consumption in households per capita; x2 â€“ energy productivity; x4 â€“ renewable energy sources in heating and cooling; x5 â€“ renewable energy sources in transport; x6â€“ renewable energy sources in electricity; x7â€“ final energy consumption; Destimulants are such variables which smaller values mean the higher level of development of complex socio- economic studied process. In the research x3 â€“ population unable to keep home adequately warm by poverty status ; x8â€“ primary energy consumption; x9â€“ energy import dependency by products has destimulant character. While nominants are such variables, which desired values are within a specific range. Stage 4. Defining the diagnostic variables weight In the research problem such of variables was non-statistical information used, in which the weights are usually determined by the expert assessment method, they are so-called substantive weights. Stage 5. Normalization of variables The variables can occur in the data base in different units of measure, which additionally hinder any arithmetic operations. Therefore, the next stage in the construction of the measure of development is normalizing variables. In the research the variables was normalized according of formula: ?Ì�?ï¿½ï¿½ = ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ , (4) ð�‘Žï¿½ = ð�‘¥ï¿½ï¿½ âˆ’ ?Ì…?, (5) Stage 6. Determination of pattern and anti-pattern In the research the pattern and anti-pattern was automatically determined. For the variables which has stimulant character the pattern was constructed based on the first quartiles and third quartile for variable values which have destimulants character. For the anti-pattern was third quartile for variable values which have stimulants and first quartiles for destimulans. Stage 7-8. Construction of the aggregate measure and Classification of objects The last two stages of the VMCM method is construction of the aggregate measure and classification of objects. The value of the aggregate measure is within the range from zero to one. The aggregate measure value equal to zero for anti-pattern and value equal to one for the pattern. The object's which have the value of measure more than one are better than the pattern. Objects that are worse than the anti-pattern will have a negative value of measure. In order to better visualize the results of calculations, objects can be divided into classes with similar measurement values. In the research we have four class: class number I is for best object, class II for a good object, class III is for object which have mean value of the aggregate measure and class IV for the lowest value of the aggregate measure. Piotr Ogonowski et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4943â€“4951 4947 Piotr Ogonowski/ Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 5 3. Results and discussion Experiment - estimation of the implementation of SDG 7 Affordable and Clean Energy on the example of ranking of 29 EU countries The study used data from the Eurostat database to estimate the of the implementation of SDG 7 Affordable and Clean Energy. As the case study in the paper assessed of the SDG 7 was made according to nine indicators: x1 â€“ final energy consumption in households per capita; x2 â€“ energy productivity; x3 â€“ population unable to keep home adequately warm by poverty status; x4 â€“ renewable energy sources in heating and cooling; x5 â€“ renewable energy sources in transport; x6 â€“ renewable energy sources in electricity; x7 â€“ final energy consumption; x8 â€“ primary energy consumption; x9 â€“ energy import dependency by products. All nine indicators were collected from Eurostat, for the analysis. In the analysis ware included 27 countries from European Union and two which are not from EU but are in Schengen zone (Norway and Iceland). Longitudinal data also from 9 years (2012 â€“ 2021) was analyzed, which allows to answer the question, whether of the implementation of SDG 7 is changing over time. Fig. 1 Result of ranking the first class of EU countries, for the data from (2012-2021) year, in terms realization of SDG 7 with the use of VMCM From the figure 1, it can be concluded that the situation in Norway (NO) end Iceland (IS) in terms of development, the implementation of SDG 7 has been stable since, because since 2015 they have been in the top position in the ranking among 29 given analyzes of EU countries in first class among the best. In 2014 Norway's position dropped in the ranking from first place to secend but only for a year. This change results from the fact that of indicator x1 - final energy consumption in households per capita of the nature of stimulants decreased end Sweden there was a one-off increase of 50%. The highest class 1 is observed in 5 EU countries: Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Iceland, Austria. Fig. 2. Result of ranking the second class of EU countries, for the data from (2012-2021) year, in terms realization of SDG 7 with the use of VMCM. 2,5 3 3,5 4 4,5 5 5,5 6 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 M ea su re Sweden Norway Austria Iceland Denmark 0,5 1 1,5 2 2,5 3 3,5 4 4,5 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 M ea su re Finland Germany France Luxembourg Ireland Latvia Italy Slovenia 4948 Piotr Ogonowski et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4943â€“49516 Piotr Ogonowski/ Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 From the second graphs it can be concluded that the situation in the second class is stable, most of the objects have not changed their position in the ranking except Finland. In 2013-2017 Finland increased position in the ranking from second class to first class among the best. This change in results is may be due to the fact that the percentage of x4 â€“ renewable energy sources in heating and cooling (in %) having the stimulants character, increased. Moreover, of 2017 the values of variable, x9 â€“ energy import dependency by products, having the destimulants character, increased. The position of Finland in the ranking decreased (2017-2021) to the second class. Fig. 3. Result of ranking the third class of EU countries, for the data from (2012-2021) year, in terms realization of SDG 7 with the use of VMCM. From the third graph it can be concluded that the situation in the third class is stable, most of the objects have not changed their position in the ranking. In 2019-2021, a slight increase in Estonia can be noticed. This change in results is may be due to the fact that the percentage of x5 â€“ renewable energy sources in transport (in %) having the stimulants character, increased about 95%. Detailed data in this respect are presented in Graph 3. Fig. 4. Result of ranking the fourth class of EU countries, for the data from (2012-2021) year, in terms realization of SDG 7 with the use of VMCM. In class 4 are four EU countries: Cyprus, Bulgaria, Marta and Greece illustrated in graph 4. Form the figure 4 it can be concluded that the value of the aggregate measure for Bulgaria is decreased. This fact may be due to the high level he percentage of x3 â€“ population unable to keep home adequately warm by poverty status (29th position in 2012- 2021). Detailed data in this respect are presented in graph 4. 0 0,5 1 1,5 2 2,5 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 M ea su re Netherlands Belgium Czechia Croatia Estonia Hungary Romania Poland Slovakia Spain Portugal Lithuania -1,2 -1 -0,8 -0,6 -0,4 -0,2 0 0,2 0,4 0,6 0,8 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 M ea su re Greece Cyprus Malta Bulgaria Piotr Ogonowski et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4943â€“4951 4949 Piotr Ogonowski/ Procedia Computer Science 00 (2019) 000â€“000 7 Fig. 5 (a) and (b). Result of ranking the first and second class of UE countries, for the data from (2012-2021) year, in terms of the dynamics of realization of SDG 7 with the use of VMCM Fig. 6 (a) and (b). Result of ranking the third and fourth class of UE countries, for the data from (2012-2021) year, in terms of the dynamics of realization of SDG 7 with the use of VMCM Figures 5 and 6 present the results of the dynamics of realization of SDG 7 in 29 European countries. As a reference point was artificial pattern based on the data from 2012. Form the figures it can be concluded the goal achievement in each countries has tends to increase. Figure 5a and 5b shows that Finland, Norway and Sweden has the highest dynamics of realization of SDG 7 compared to 2012 year. 4. Conclusions Energy is one of important elements of socio-economic development, and its availability has a significant impact on improving the quality of life. Energy enables the smooth functioning of all economic sectors, from micro-enterprises to large business, from agriculture to mining, manufacturing, construction and services. SDG 7 calls for ensuring universal access to modern energy services, improving energy efficiency and increasing the share of renewable energy. To assess the complex socio-economic issue described by many indicators usually we use the multidimensional comparative analysis method. The VMCM method, as other multi-criteria methods, makes it possible to evaluate 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 10 20 12 20 13 20 14 20 15 20 16 20 17 20 18 20 19 20 20 20 21 M ea su re Sweden Norway Austria Iceland Denmark 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 20 12 20 13 20 14 20 15 20 16 20 17 20 18 20 19 20 20 20 21 M ea su re Finland Germany France Luxembourg Ireland Latvia Italy Slovenia a) b) -1,5 -1 -0,5 0 0,5 1 1,5 2 2,5 20 12 20 13 20 14 20 15 20 16 20 17 20 18 20 19 20 20 20 21 M ea su re Greece Cyprus Malta Bulgaria b) 0,5 1 1,5 2 2,5 3 3,5 4 4,5 20 12 20 13 20 14 20 15 20 16 20 17 20 18 20 19 20 20 20 21 M ea su re Netherlands Belgium Czechia Croatia Estonia Hungary Romania Poland Slovakia Spain Portugal Lithuania a) 4950 Piotr Ogonowski et al. / Procedia Computer Science 225 (2023) 4943â€“49518 Piotr Ogonowski/ Procedia Computer Science 00 (2023) 000â€“000 variants based on defined criteria and conduct a ranking process. In the experiment, the Vector Measure Construction Methods will be used to assess the realization of SDG7 for the European Union countries. In the analysis ware included 29 countries from European countries. The study used data from the Eurostat database to estimate the of the implementation of SDG 7 â€“ (affordable and clean energy). Longitudinal data from 9 years (2012 â€“ 2021) was analysed, which allows to answer the question, whether of the implementation of SDG 7 is changing over time. In order to assess the of the implementation of SDG 7 of the European Union countries, studies were conducted based on 9 selected indicators. Research has shown in terms of the implementation of SDG 7 indicators, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Iceland, Austria with the highest value of the aggregate measurements and were in the first class. In 2014 Norway's position dropped in the ranking from first place to secend but only for a year. This change results from the fact that of indicator x1 - final energy consumption in households per capita of the nature of stimulants decreased and Sweden there was a one-off increase of 50%. In additional it can be concluded that the situation has changed in the second class, in 2013- 2017. Finland increased position in the ranking from second class to first class among the best. This change in results is may be due to the fact that the percentage of x4 â€“ renewable energy sources in heating and cooling (in %) having the stimulants character, increased. Whereas of 2017 the values of variable, x9 â€“ energy import dependency by products, having the destimulants character, increased. The position of Finland in the ranking decreased (2017-2021) to the second class. In 2019-2021, in the third class, a slight increase Estonia can be noticed. This change in results is may be due to the fact that the percentage of x5 â€“ renewable energy sources in transport, (in %) having the stimulants character, increased about 95%. An additional it can be concluded that in class 4 the value of the aggregate measure for Bulgaria is decreased. This fact may be due to the high level he percentage of x3 â€“ population unable to keep home adequately warm by poverty status (29 th position in 2012-2021). The goal-level assessment of SDG 7 â€“ (affordable and clean energy) is strongly influenced by the measures taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the related restrictions (schools, cinemas, shopping centers closed) on public life and lower economic activity. In contrast, the Russian-Western standoff due to the invasion of Ukraine has produced an unprecedented increase in energy prices, especially in Europe. It is important to note that the increase in energy prices already observed in 2021 is not yet reflected in these data the Eurostat. The results of the analysis showed that applying VMCM method to assess the of the implementation SDG 7 is very useful and provides better understanding of multidimensional data. head.ce:title: Application of VMCM method to assess the implementation of Sustainable Development Goal 7 in EU countries

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institute Management, University of Szczecin, Cukrowa 8, 71 004 Szczecin, Poland
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: aInstitute Management, University of Szczecin, Cukrowa 8, 71 004 Szczecin, Poland

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Everyday life and the workings of the economy depend on reliable and affordable energy services, such as electricity supply. Guaranteeing universal access to sustainable energy services is fundamental for socioeconomic development. This paper assessed the implementation of the sustainable development goal in the European Union countries in the seventh area "Affordable and clean energy" out of seventeen Sustainable Development Goals (SDG7) formulated in the document “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”. To assess the implementation of the seventh objective, the VMCM method was used, which allows for the ranking and classification of objects described with many features as representing the dynamics of changes in the studied phenomenon. As a result, each EU country was assigned to one of four classes appointed by the level of goal achievement SDG7. The country with the highest value of level of goal were assigned to Class 1, while those measured the lowest were assigned to Class 4. It presented in dynamic perspective comparing changes over 9 years (since year 2012 to 2021).
